column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Kapambwe (Zambia): I have the honour to\r
#Text=address the Security Council on behalf of the member\r
#Text=States of the Southern African Development\r
#Text=Community (SADC) - namely, Angola, Botswana, the\r
#Text=Democratic Republic of the Congo, Lesotho,\r
#Text=Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique,\r
#Text=Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, the United Republic\r
#Text=of Tanzania, Zimbabwe and my own country, Zambia.
#Text=We would like to thank the Secretary-General, the\r
#Text=Special Adviser to the Secretary General on Gender\r
#Text=Issues and Advancement of Women, the Under-\r
#Text=Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations, the Ad\r
#Text=Interim Executive Director of the United Nations\r
#Text=Development Fund for Women and the Coordinator of\r
#Text=the NGO Working Group on Women, Peace and\r
#Text=Security for their introductory statements, which were\r
#Text=very instructive.
#Text=SADC welcomes the opportunity, on the seventh\r
#Text=anniversary of the adoption of the landmark resolution\r
#Text=1325 (2000), to participate in this open debate on\r
#Text=women, peace and security, focused on achieving\r
#Text=coherent and effective implementation of Security\r
#Text=Council resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=As we are all aware,\r
#Text=the resolution, among other things, calls for the\r
#Text=incorporation of a gender perspective in negotiating\r
#Text=\r
#Text=and implementing peace agreements, planning refugee\r
#Text=camps and peacekeeping operations, and reconstructing\r
#Text=war-torn societies.
#Text=Today's debate therefore provides\r
#Text=us with an opportunity to assess the concrete and\r
#Text=specific efforts in the implementation of the resolution\r
#Text=at all levels and the role of the Security Council in such\r
#Text=efforts.
#Text=The adoption of resolution 1325 (2000) by the\r
#Text=Security Council and the six subsequent presidential\r
#Text=statements on women, peace and security provide a\r
#Text=solid framework for action in all areas of the peace\r
#Text=process.
#Text=The importance of women's equal\r
#Text=participation and full involvement in all efforts to\r
#Text=maintain and promote peace and security cannot be\r
#Text=overstated.
#Text=While some progress has been made in the\r
#Text=implementation of the resolution, greater coordinated\r
#Text=efforts are required to achieve the goal of full\r
#Text=implementation.
#Text=In that regard, SADC calls on the\r
#Text=international community to render sustained support in\r
#Text=the development of national action plans, including\r
#Text=financial and human resources, that will eventually\r
#Text=drive the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=We thank the Secretary-General for his report,\r
#Text=contained in document S/2007/567, on women and\r
#Text=peace and security.
#Text=The report reviews and monitors\r
#Text=the implementation of the 2005-2007 United Nations\r
#Text=System-wide Action Plan and identifies gaps and\r
#Text=challenges, including in the areas of funding of gender\r
#Text=projects and insufficient institutional capacity for\r
#Text=gender mainstreaming.
#Text=We must address those\r
#Text=challenges if we are to obtain the desired results.
#Text=We\r
#Text=welcome the recommendations contained in the report,\r
#Text=which we believe will contribute to the acceleration of\r
#Text=the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=We would like to commend the Inter-agency\r
#Text=Network on Women and Gender Equality, the Inter-\r
#Text=Agency Task Force on Women, Peace and Security, and\r
#Text=the Office of the Special Adviser on Gender Issues and\r
#Text=Advancement of Women for their commendable work\r
#Text=in coming up with a holistic and coherent 2008-2009\r
#Text=United Nations System-wide Action Plan, which will\r
#Text=serve as a results-based programme and monitoring and\r
#Text=reporting tool.
#Text=The responsibility of ensuring the full\r
#Text=realization of the Plan rests with the international\r
#Text=community.
#Text=The Security Council should hold national\r
#Text=Governments accountable for the implementation of\r
#Text=the Action Plan.
#Text=The high number of victims of violence continues\r
#Text=to be a concern for SADC.
#Text=We are saddened that\r
#Text=women continue to bear the brunt of grave violations\r
#Text=of human rights, including violence and sexual abuses.
#Text=We condemn all those parties that perpetuate acts of\r
#Text=violence and abuse against women and children.
#Text=We\r
#Text=call for the speedy investigation of all cases of Violence\r
#Text=and sexual abuse, especially those committed against\r
#Text=women and children.
#Text=The culture of impunity must be\r
#Text=stopped by, among other things, bringing to justice all\r
#Text=the perpetrators.
#Text=SADC is encouraged by the progress on\r
#Text=mainstreaming gender in relevant policies and\r
#Text=programmes on disarmament, demobilization and\r
#Text=reintegration (DDR).
#Text=It is necessary to recognize the\r
#Text=needs of women and girl ex-combatants in the DDR\r
#Text=process and to ensure that their concerns are taken on\r
#Text=board from the planning stages.
#Text=We commend the work\r
#Text=that has been done by the United Nations Children's\r
#Text=Fund in reintegration projects that has led to the release\r
#Text=of girls from the armed forces in various countries.
#Text=We commend the various United Nations\r
#Text=agencies that have undertaken capacity-building\r
#Text=efforts, including the development of the training\r
#Text=models.
#Text=We would, however, request that there be\r
#Text=synergy and coherence in the various training models\r
#Text=produced.
#Text=We wish to reiterate that awareness of\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000) needs to be broadened and that\r
#Text=capacities at the national level to implement the\r
#Text=resolution need to be enhanced.
#Text=In that endeavour, we\r
#Text=wish to underscore the importance of building capacity\r
#Text=at the local level and, in particular, the capacity of\r
#Text=national and local women's groups on the ground.
#Text=Experience has shown that the participation of\r
#Text=women in peace processes produces positive results,\r
#Text=especially because they, together with children, are the\r
#Text=major victims of atrocities committed in conflict.
#Text=Women need to hold decision-making positions.
#Text=It is\r
#Text=imperative that women be encouraged and supported to\r
#Text=run for offices, especially in countries emerging from\r
#Text=conflicts.
#Text=In that regard, we wish to commend the work\r
#Text=undertaken by United Nations agencies in facilitating\r
#Text=the promotion and effective participation of women in\r
#Text=decision-making processes.
#Text=In conclusion, I wish to state that SADC remains\r
#Text=committed to the full and effective implementation of\r
#Text=Security Council resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=We in the\r
#Text=international community have an obligation to ensure\r
#Text=that the rights of women the world over are protected\r
#Text=and that their place in all aspects of the peace process\r
#Text=is assured.
#Text=It is their equal participation and their full\r
#Text=involvement that will contribute to the effective\r
#Text=maintenance and promotion of sustainable peace and\r
#Text=security.
